items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Following rainfall overnight lake levels remain high on Derwent Water. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around lake shore of Derwent Water. Further showers are forecast throughout the day. Lake levels are forecast to begin falling slowly, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 17:15 on Sunday 27th November and 4.72mAOD at 04:45 on Monday 28th November.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 96 cubic metres per second and is steady, but is expected to rise in response to recent rainfall over the next couple of days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on Monday 28th November, or as the situation changes.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill areas. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Further rainfall is forecast today. Levels have stabilised on the Wey but will remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. No further rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby road, the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. No further rainfall is forecast however the river is not expected to drop below the flood risk threshold until Wednesday, 30/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels have risen again at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
  We expect river levels to begin falling at 20:00 on 27/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Monday, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Levels have stabilised on the Chertsey Bourne but remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but falling at the Willington and Shardlow river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high overnight tonight and tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, and tide levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding is expected, however, please take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday 29/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00, 28/11/2022 or as the situation changes.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. 
We continue to monitor the situation.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels have fallen at the Llanymynech river gauge but levels remain high at Cae Howel following heavy rainfall over the last 2 days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Llanymynech peaked at 3.58m on 25/11/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message: River levels remain high in the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to last nights rainfall.  No further significant rainfall is forecast but we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in the areas should consider taking action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Uck is high in Isfield, following 20mm of rain on Sunday morning. In Isfield, flood water will continue to affect fields, rural roads and properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Between Buxted and Uckfield, the River Uck is currently falling, with only minimal flood impacts expected. Another 5 - 15mm of rain could fall between 17:00 and 23:00 on Sunday evening, with showers on Monday too. River levels will likely rise again in Buxted and Uckfield. Minor flood impacts are possible again, affecting riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart Pub, and at Hempstead Mill, The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage and Bell Walk, Uckfield. Rivers should peak lower than they were at midday on Sunday and begin to fall by 05:00 on Monday 28/11/2022. Levels will remain higher than normal until midweek. Please keep flood protection products installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We will close our flood gate in the supermarket car park in Uckfield town centre on Sunday to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected to continue through Sunday evening, 27/11/2022 and overnight into Monday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads is expected around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst and around Balls Green.   
Further light rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday evening 27/11/2022. We expect river levels to remain high until 08:00am on 28/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Medway. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of persistent rainfall overnight and today, Sunday 27 November. We expect river levels to remain high and respond to further rainfall tonight. Further scattered showers are forecast tomorrow morning, Monday 28 November. River levels are likely to remain high for the next few days. 
 
Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible close to the river. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue flood warnings if necessary.
 
This message will be updated by 8am on Monday 28 November, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising following 15mm of rain on Sunday morning. Flooding will continue to affect gardens and properties near Mock Bridge. Water will be extensive through fields and affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. The rainfall forecast remains uncertain, but another 5 - 10mm of rain could fall this Sunday evening, with showers on Monday too. If the higher amounts of rain fall overnight, there is a chance we will issue a Flood Warning. River levels might not begin to fall until midday on Monday 28/11/2022, remaining higher than normal until midweek. However, river levels will probably stay lower than heights of recent peaks. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please take proactive action to reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 25mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. This is a modest amount, but it follows weeks of prolonged wet weather. Today (Sunday 27/11/22) flooding of roads (including Golf Links Road and from early evening, Moreton Common Road), cycle tracks, footpaths and gardens will occur throughout the Yar Valley. The main band of rain has now cleared the area, but further showers are expected on Sunday afternoon and into Monday (28/11/22) with 10-20mm forecast. At Alverstone, the river may continue to rise until 18:00 this evening, at Sandown, it is unlikely to peak until the early hours of Monday morning. It is unlikely that property flooding will occur over the next 24 hours, however this is very much dependent on how much rain impacts the river later on this afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding can operate. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Monday 28/11/2022, or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.

The River Ouse is high and rising between Scaynes Hill and Barcombe, following 17mm of rain on Sunday morning. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens all along the upper Ouse and approach riverside properties on Sloop Lane, at Fletching Mill Bridge and at Sharpsbridge as well as the Anchor Inn and isolated properties at Barcombe Mills. More heavy rain (10-20mm) is possible between 17:00 and 23:00 Sunday evening, with showers Monday (28/11/2022). Sunday evening's rain could cause the River Ouse to rise higher in all communities. If the higher amounts of rain fall overnight, isolated property flooding might just be possible and there is a chance we will issue a Flood Warning for Barcombe Mills. In Barcombe the river might not begin to fall until Monday morning and return nearer to normal until midweek. Please keep flood protection products in place in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/11/2022.

The Bull River through Cuckmere is high and rising, following 20mm of rain Sunday morning (27/11/2022). Flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. More heavy rain (10-20mm) is possible between 17:00 and 23:00 Sunday evening. River levels through Hellingly could rise again, and property flooding is possible. From 21:00 on 27/11/2022 minor flood impacts could also be possible on Mill Lane Hellingly and at Grove Hill. From 01:00 on 28/11/2022 flooding will also affect North Street, Litlington Road, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Showers are forecast Monday, but next week should be drier. Rivers should begin to fall by midday Monday but will remain higher than normal until midweek.  Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected Sunday evening, 27/11/2022 and overnight into Monday, 28/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Crowhurst Bridge area, Shrub Lane and Robertsbridge.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday evening 27/11/2022 although some uncertainty remains in totals. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday lunchtime 28/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Rother. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen as a result of persistent rainfall overnight and today, Sunday 27 November. We expect river levels to remain high and respond to further rainfall tonight. Further scattered showers are forecast tomorrow morning, Monday 28 November. River levels are likely to remain high for the next few days. 
 
Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible around Kinnersley Manor. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue flood warnings if necessary. 
 
This message will be updated by 8am on Monday 28 November, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall combined with high tides. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 9pm Sunday, 27/11/2022 overnight into Monday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in the Maidstone area and along the River Medway around Aylesford.  
Further rainfall is forecast until 11pm 27/11/2022. We expect river levels to remain high until 8am Monday, 28/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected through Sunday evening and overnight, 27/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Water Lane and Haxted Road.   
Further rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday evening 27/11/2022 although some uncertainty remains in totals. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Eden and its tributaries. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high and rising between Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth, following 20mm of rain Sunday morning. Flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Only minor flood impacts are currently expected in Liss, Sheet, Iping and Midhurst, where the Western Rother is now slowly falling. The rainfall forecast remains uncertain. Another 5-10mm of rain could fall Sunday evening, with showers Monday (28/11/2022). The river should initially begin to fall by 22:00 Sunday at Lodsbridge near Selham, but not until 10:00 Monday (28/11/2022) in Fittleworth. If the higher amounts of rain fall overnight, there is a chance the Western Rother might not fall until Monday afternoon. The Western Rother in Fttleworth might not return nearer to normal until midweek. River levels should hopefully stay lower than recent peaks. Please keep flood protection products in place at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/11/2022.

River levels in Crowhurst are still very high following 30mm of rain Sunday morning (27/11/2022). Flooding will continue to affect riverside properties in Crowhurst, potentially affecting properties on Forewood Lane and properties between The Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Flood water will also affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, and Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Another 10-20mm of rain could fall between 17:00 and 23:00 Sunday evening, with showers Monday too. If this rain occurs, property flooding in Crowhurst is possible from 20:00 Sunday evening 27/11/2022. The Powdermill Stream should fall by 05:00 Monday 28/11/2022 but will remain higher than normal until midweek. At Bulverhythe, river levels will remain higher than normal all week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Crowhurst, as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/11/2022.

Monday's early morning tide at 02:00 on 28/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by recent high energy waves. Winds are light Westerly Force 4. The weather increases tide table values by 0.30 m. The total forecast tide is 6.01 metres Chart Datum (2.96 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday's afternoon tide is predicted to be 30cm lower. Minor flood impacts are expected until Tuesday (29/11/2022). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 28/11/2022.

The River Arun is high between Horsham and Pulborough, following 20mm of rain Sunday morning. River levels are rising between Broadbridge Heath and Pulborough, where flood water will affect fields, rural roads and gardens of isolated mill properties. Including possibly the A272 Newbridge Road near Billingshurst from the early hours of Monday. In Horsham, river levels are falling but minor flooding will continue to affect grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and possibly fields behind Arunside and the playground of Arunside School. A further 5-10mm of rain is possible Sunday evening, with showers on Monday too. The river should initially begin to fall by 22:00 27/11/2022 in and near Broadbridge Heath, but not until midday Monday nearer Pulborough. The River Arun will be higher than normal until midweek. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford as a precaution, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 11:00 28/11/2022.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high and rising. 30mm of rain was recorded at Westergate Sunday morning. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco, Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Only minor flood impacts are expected in Barnham, where river levels are currently slowly falling. Another 5-10mm of rain could fall Sunday evening, with showers on Monday too. The Aldingbourne Rife might not begin to fall until midday Monday and will be higher than normal all week. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 28/11/2022.

items.message:
The river level on the Washford River at Beggearn Huish is slowly falling but continues to remain above the flood alert level. All other rivers in the area are at safe levels. The rainfall has now passed out of the area and drier weather is forecast for the next few days. The impact of flooding is now not expected to increase, and no flooding of properties is likely. 
This flood alert may be removed later today or will be updated by 12:00 on Monday, 28/11/2022. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the last 2 days.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.message: River levels remain high in the Upper Dorset Frome and Hooke River following last nights heavy rainfall.  No further heavy rainfall is expected but we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.  Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen again at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   
  We expect river levels to begin falling at 15:00 on 27/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Monday, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.88 m and is currently rising at 15 mm an hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.28 m and currently stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m and the road from Muchelney to Long load above 7.86 m. Pumping will take place at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station when river levels allow.
The rainfall has now passed out of the area and drier weather is forecast for the next few days. The risk of flooding of low-lying land and road continues but is not forecast to increase and property flooding is not expected.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Monday, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 7pm today, Sunday 27/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the Great Stour and the East Stour, particularly in and around Ashford.
Further rainfall is forecast until 11pm on Sunday 27/11/2022. We expect river levels to remain high until 10am on Monday.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily on the Lower Dorset Frome due to the heavy rainfall overnight.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham. Flooding is possible at tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham from 05:00 PM on 27/11/2022.  There is no further significant rainfall forecast but there may be a small chance of some localised showers.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. However, there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 17 mm has been recorded in Romsey. This is only a modest amount of rain but follows weeks of prolonged wet weather. From 12:00 today (Sunday 27/11/22) the river will begin to flood land fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. The water level will also be very high around the mill at East Wellow. The main band of rain has now cleared the area, but further rain and showers are expected on Sunday afternoon and into Monday (28/11/22) with 10-20mm forecast. We currently expect the river will rise until at least 18:00 this evening (27/11/22). Over the next 24 hours, water levels will be much higher than normal. Property flooding is not currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 28/11/22.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.48 m and has just started to slowly fall. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.93m and is slowly rising at approximately 5 mm an hour. Pumping will take place at Currymoor when the river levels allow. 
The rainfall has now passed out of the area and drier weather is forecast for the next few days. The risk of flooding of low-lying land and roads continues but is not forecast to increase and property flooding is not expected.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Monday, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

The risk of flooding from the River Witham has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam and Frisby river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding of farm land and low lying roads in the Melton and Asfordby areas, including Station Lane Ashfordly including low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 7pm Sunday 27/11/2022 into tomorrow, Monday 28/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the New Romney Sewage Arm, particularly around Greatstone.   
Further rainfall is forecast Sunday evening until 11pm. We expect river levels to remain high until 8am Monday 28/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are deploying pumps, people and equipment and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels continue to remain high on the Lower River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. No further significant rainfall is expected today, Sunday 27/11/2022, or tomorrow Monday 28/11/2022, but river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the middle to lower part of the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially in the areas around Thrupp. We are expecting showery rain this afternoon (Sunday). We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Monday, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the last 2 days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Glaze catchment including Leigh and East Wigan
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels remain high but have fallen below the flood risk threshold. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in this area today, Sunday 27/11/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of Persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 17/11/22  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   Flood water could be deep and fast flowing, and therefore pose a risk to life.
Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  River levels can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Monday, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Recent heavy bands of rain have caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

River levels have risen at the Mythe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and low lying land at Quedgeley / Stonebench. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks: Mythe 3.1m to 3.3m at 00:45 on Monday morning 28/11/22. Upper Pound 3.1m to 3.3m at 00:45 on Monday morning 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides are due today Sunday 27/11/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.3m to 3.5m at 00:15 am Monday 28/11/22 and 3.1m to 3.3m at 12:30pm Monday. Gloucester 3.1m to 3.3m at midnight tonight and 2.8m to 3.0m at 12:30pm Monday. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but beginning to fall at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding may still be affecting low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting the racecourse and the Worcester County cricket ground. Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 5.36m at 3am Saturday morning , 26/11/22.  Diglis peaked at 3.22m Friday evening, 25/11/22. Worcester peaked at 3.52m Friday evening, 25/11/22,  Saxons Lode peaked at 4.09m Saturday morning, 26/11/22 .River levels are falling but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have peaked and are beginning to fall slowly.
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are high but beginning to fall at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding may still be affecting low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 5.36m at 3am Saturday morning , 26/11/22.  River levels are falling but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The width of shingle beach, which protects property at Eastoke Corner is narrower than normal, following a very high energy wave event on Thursday (24/11/22). However, forecast tide levels and wave heights are now reducing and are much lower than they were last week.  Given the current forecast, it is unlikely that further flooding of gardens and roads will occur. We continue to liaise with the local authority and emergency response team over the condition of the beach at Eastoke and we will issue further messages when necessary.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock. This is as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Water may remains on roads and farmland however further flooding is not expected for the next 24 hours. We are expecting showery rain this afternoon (Sunday). We expect river levels to remain high on the river Glyme over the next few days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Monday, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week and more recently overnight on Saturday. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue around Islip. We are expecting showery rain this afternoon (Sunday). We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Monday, or as the situation changes.

Monday's early morning tide at 02:00 on 28/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by recent high energy waves. Winds are light Westerly Force 4. The weather increases tide table values by 0.30 m. The total forecast tide is 6.01 metres Chart Datum (2.96 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday's afternoon tide is predicted to be 30cm lower. Minor flood impacts are expected until Tuesday (29/11/2022). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. As a precaution, please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 10:00 on 28/11/2022.

The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 10am on 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brit at Newtown, and Southgate Old Mill, Beaminster
Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester
items.message: River levels remain high in the Upper River Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester.  Areas in Higher Frome Vauchurch, Frome Vauchurch, Cruxton, Frampton, Grimstone, Muckleford, Stratton, Bradford Peverell, Wrackleford, Charminster, Frome Whitfield, Wolfeton, Lower Burton and Cokers Frome are at risk.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. People in this area should take action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Briantspuddle river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.   Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham   We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
Further showery rain forecast over the next few hours.  River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further significant rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Monday, 28/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Leach as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Therefore, flooding of low laying land is expected to continue, specifically in the area around Lechlade.   
We are expecting showery rain this afternoon (Sunday). River levels have are expected to slowly rise, but then stabilise over the next day or two.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been operating weirs to reduce flood risk. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Monday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been high on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Therefore, flooding of low laying land is expected to continue, specifically between Sandford Lock and Abingdon Lock.   
We are expecting showery rain this afternoon (Sunday). River levels have are not expected to get much higher than they currently are but are expected to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been operating weirs to reduce flood risk. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Monday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from East Stoke to Wareham
items.message: River levels are high and rising on the Lower River Frome between Dorchester and Wareham due to the heavy overnight rainfall.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations on the River Frome in the East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham areas.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from Dorchester to East Stoke
items.message: River levels are high and rising on the Lower River Frome between Dorchester and Wareham due to the heavy overnight rainfall.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations on the River Frome in the Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool and East Stoke areas.  No further heavy rainfall is expected but we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 9pm today, 27/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the Speringbrook Sewer, particularly around Hamstreet.   
Further rainfall is forecast until 1am on 28/11/2022. We expect river levels to remain high until 8am Monday morning. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are deploying pumps, people and equipment to the area and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 8pm Sunday 27/11/2022 into tomorrow, Monday 28/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Tillingham between Broad Oak and Rye.   
Further rainfall is forecast Sunday evening until 11pm. We expect river levels to remain high until 8am Monday 28/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are deploying pumps, people and equipment and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
